item.title: NASA Begins Astronaut Space Station Medical Evacuation: What to Know
item.description: Four astronauts departed from the I.S.S. about a month earlier than scheduled because a crew member, who was not identified, has an undisclosed medical issue.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: The International Space Station crew members in their Crew Dragon pressure suits on Jan. 9. Clockwise from bottom left: NASA astronaut Mike Fincke, Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov, NASA astronaut Zena Cardman and JAXA astronaut Kimiya Yui.

item.title: Toby Kiers, World Champion of Mycorrhizal Fungus
item.description: This year’s recipient of the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement talks about “punk science,” microbial economics and thinking like a mycorrhizal fungus.
item.dc:creator: Alan Burdick
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

item.title: What a Wolf Pup’s Stomach Revealed About the Woolly Rhino’s Extinction
item.description: Scientists prepared a high-quality sequence of the giant mammal’s genome based on a specimen preserved in Siberian permafrost.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: The Sea Lions of the Galápagos Are Not Ready to Give Up Mother’s Milk
item.description: Animals that researchers call “supersucklers” come back to nurse even after they can hunt, mate and fend for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Why This Fish Actually Needs a Hole in the Head
item.description: A cavity in the middle of the rockhead poacher’s skull might be used like a maraca to produce sound, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.media:credit: Daniel Geldof, LSU Advanced Microscopy and Analytics Core
item.media:description: To solve the mystery, Mr. Geldof used a micro-CT scanner to scan the fish’s anatomy.

item.title: This Dinosaur Really Knew How to Get a Grip
item.description: A fossil of Manipulonyx reshetovi, found in a Mongolian desert, shows how the dinosaur used its specialized claw to snatch eggs.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.category: Proceedings of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences (Journal)

item.title: Trump’s Steep Science Budget Cuts to Be Turned Back by Congress
item.description: After the White House called for billions of dollars in funding reductions, senators and representatives said they wanted to safeguard and even boost funds for basic research.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Each year, the president submits a budget request to Congress in advance of the annual appropriations process, but only Congress has the power of the purse.

item.title: Google’s Ex-CEO Backs Start-Up Approach to Big Telescopes for Space and Astronomy
item.description: Eric and Wendy Schmidt are backing a start-up-like approach to building a giant space telescope and powerful ground observatories.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Schmidt Sciences

item.title: Scientists Discover Cloud-9, a Starless ‘Galaxy That Wasn’t’
item.description: Astronomers announced the discovery of a starless cloud of hydrogen gas, a pristine relic of the cosmos that is almost as old as time itself.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: NASA, ESA, VLA, Gagandeep Anand (STScI), Alejandro Benitez-Llambay (University of Milano-Bicocca)
item.media:description: Cloud-9, 14 million light-years from Earth, with radio data collected from the Very Large Array in New Mexico revealing the cloud in magenta. The circle marks the peak of radio emissions, where researchers focused their search for stars.

item.title: What happens during the astronauts’ return to Earth?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA, via Reuters
item.media:description: A Crew Dragon capsule undocking from the space station last March.

item.title: Is it risky to fly a sick astronaut home to Earth?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Keegan Barber/NASA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A SpaceX capsule landing in the Pacific Ocean off the Southern California coast last August.

item.title: Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Kaiser Permanente Agrees to Pay $556 Million to Settle Medicare Overbilling Claims
item.description: The Justice Department and whistle-blowers accused the major health insurer of overbilling the government for about $1 billion under the private plans.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. James Taylor, a physician and coding expert who worked for Kaiser Permanente, was one of the whistle-blowers who flagged the overbilling. “The cash monster was insatiable,” he said.

item.title: Weather Detours a Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Bad weather has postponed attempts to set up camp on the Thwaites Glacier. So researchers got onto the sea ice and met a local.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Extreme Weather Events Hit Around the World in 2025
item.description: Last year was Earth’s third hottest globally, but temperature is just one measure of climate change’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palisades Fire burning along the Pacific Coast Highway early last January.

item.title: E.P.A. Moves to Limit States’ Ability to Block Pipelines
item.description: The agency wants to curtail a section of the Clean Water Act that Democratic governors have used to restrict fossil fuel development.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas pipeline under construction near Amarillo, Texas, in November.

item.title: Initial Obamacare Enrollment Drops by 1.4 Million as Expiring ACA Subsidies Drive Up Premiums
item.description: That number could increase significantly as more consumers are faced with higher bills brought on by expiring premium subsidies.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: An insurance sales office in Miami-Dade County in October.

item.title: Medical Groups Will Try to Block Childhood Vaccine Recommendations
item.description: The groups, including the American Academy of Pediatrics, say the C.D.C.’s revised vaccine schedule is not based on scientific evidence and will harm the public.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bypassing longstanding protocol for vaccine decisions, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the Health Department cut the number of vaccines recommended for children to 11 from 17.

item.title: A Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier Deals With Weather Hiccups
item.description: The clock is ticking. But low clouds have prevented helicopters from moving scientists and gear onto the continent’s fastest-melting glacier.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Emissions Jumped in 2025 as Coal Power Rebounded
item.description: The increase in planet-warming emissions came after two years of decline as demand for electricity has been surging.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Charlie Riedel/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant near Emmett, Kan. Demand for power has started surging in recent years amid a boom in data centers, an upswing of domestic manufacturing and the spread of electric vehicles.

item.title: Psilocybin Leads in Psychedelic Medicine, but Rollout Is Bumpy
item.description: Psilocybin-assisted therapy is legal in three states, but access has so far been limited and expensive.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Bonny Koeber prepared a therapy room with sage before a patient arrived from New York for psilocybin therapy at Satya Therapeutics in Ashland, Ore.

item.title: China’s ‘Dr. Frankenstein’ Thinks Time Is on His Side
item.description: He Jiankui spent three years in prison after creating gene-edited babies. Now back at work, he sees a greater opening for researchers who push boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: He Jiankui, a researcher in gene editing, at his home in Beijing. He argues that his only crime was being ahead of his time in a world not yet ready for his vision.

item.title: Trump Cuts to Energy Projects in Blue States Were Unlawful, Judge Rules
item.description: The Energy Department canceled $7.5 billion in Biden-era energy spending, largely in Democratic-led states, during last year’s government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The cuts were part of a larger effort by the Energy Department to cancel spending for projects like hydrogen fuel hubs, electrical grid upgrades and efforts to reduce methane leaks.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Effort to Stop Rhode Island’s Revolution Wind Project
item.description: The ruling means that construction can continue on Revolution Wind, a $6.2 billion project off the coast of Rhode Island, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Components of the Revolution Wind farm project on a pier in New London, Conn., in September.

item.title: F.D.A. Decisions on Abortion Pill Were Based on Science, New Analysis Finds
item.description: A study of more than 5,000 pages of agency documents on mifepristone over 12 years found that agency leaders almost always followed the evidence-based recommendations of scientists.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: Under Trump, U.S. Adds Fuel to a Heating Planet
item.description: The president’s embrace of fossil fuels and withdrawal from the global fight against climate change will make it hard to keep warming at safe levels, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: America’s greenhouse gas emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas, which had finally started to decline, rose 1.9 percent after Mr. Trump returned to office.

item.title: Is Grass-Fed Beef Better?
item.description: The idea of cows grazing in a pasture seems idyllic. We asked experts how their emissions stack up compared to factory farms.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Photo by Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: New Children’s Vaccine Schedule May Not Be the Last of RFK Jr.’s Big Changes
item.description: Comments by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his allies suggest the revised schedule may presage an approach to immunization that prizes individual autonomy and downplays scientific expertise.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family nurse practitioner in a white coat administers a vaccine to a three-year-old child in Seminole, Texas.

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Louisiana’s Eroding Coast
item.description: Local governments are suing oil companies over environmental damage. The companies want the suits moved out of state courts, to friendlier venues.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil industry infrastructure near Pointe à la Hache in Plaquemines Parish, La.

item.title: Bird Flu Viruses Raise Mounting Concerns Among Scientists
item.description: Researchers are not just worried about the virus popping up on American farms. Other types are causing trouble around the world.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The milking parlor of a Wisconsin dairy farm. The Agriculture Department announced the first detection of bird flu in a herd in the state, the third time the virus had jumped from wildlife into dairy cattle last year.

item.title: An Up-Close Look at the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: From an icebreaker sailing near the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, our photographer has captured the many faces of the ice.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Joel Habener, Whose Research Led to Weight-Loss Drugs, Dies at 88
item.description: His discovery of the protein fragment GLP-1 was crucial in the development of Ozempic, Wegovy and other blockbuster obesity and diabetes treatments.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Jerome Lowenstein, 92, Dies; Teaching Doctor With a Literary Sideline
item.description: When not guiding students in a compassionate approach to patient care, he led a tiny publishing imprint that put out a much-rejected debut novel that won a surprise Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: The War Over the Weedkiller Roundup Might Be Headed to the Supreme Court
item.description: Bayer has asked the justices to decide whether federal law shields the company from lawsuits over its Roundup herbicide and cancer. Democrats and MAHA activists aren’t happy.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Seth Perlman/Associated Press
item.media:description: The herbicide Roundup, when paired with genetically modified seeds, kills weeds without damaging crops. But some evidence has indicated a link to cancer.

item.title: Dogs Build Their Vocabularies Like Toddlers
item.description: Eavesdropping on their owners seems to help some toy-crazy and talented pups learn more words.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: The Icebreaker Araon Stops Near the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Less than a day after arriving at the ice, we are already up close and personal with the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: NASA Will Bring I.S.S. Astronauts Home Early After Medical Issue
item.description: After canceling a spacewalk planned for Thursday, the space agency’s administrator said it was erring on the side of caution and bringing a crew of four home in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Steve Nesius/Reuters

item.title: The Scientists Making Antacids for the Sea to Help Counter Global Warming
item.description: The world’s oceans are becoming dangerously acidic. A controversial proposal would raise the pH — by mixing chemicals into the water.
item.dc:creator: Ferris Jabr
item.media:credit: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam Subhas of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts.
